metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: Matplotlib Markers
Markers
You can use the keyword argument marker to emphasize each point with a specified marker:
content.html: You can use the keyword argument marker to emphasize each point with a specified marker:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

ypoints = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])

plt.plot(ypoints, marker = 'o')
plt.show()

content.code:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

ypoints = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])

plt.plot(ypoints, marker = 'o')
plt.show()

syntax_highlighting.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

ypoints = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])

plt.plot(ypoints, marker = 'o')
plt.show()

content.code_html:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

ypoints = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])

plt.plot(ypoints, marker = 'o')
plt.show()

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

ypoints = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])

plt.plot(ypoints, marker = 'o')
plt.show()

content.code_html:
...
plt.plot(ypoints, marker = '*')
...

content.text: Marker Reference
You can choose any of these markers:
content.html: You can choose any of these markers:

content.code_html:
Marker Description
'o' Circle Try it »
'*' Star Try it »
'.' Point Try it »
',' Pixel Try it »
'x' X Try it »
'X' X (filled) Try it »
'+' Plus Try it »
'P' Plus (filled) Try it »
's' Square Try it »
'D' Diamond Try it »
'd' Diamond (thin) Try it »
'p' Pentagon Try it »
'H' Hexagon Try it »
'h' Hexagon Try it »
'v' Triangle Down Try it »
'^' Triangle Up Try it »
'<' Triangle Left Try it »
'>' Triangle Right Try it »
'1' Tri Down Try it »
'2' Tri Up Try it »
'3' Tri Left Try it »
'4' Tri Right Try it »
'|' Vline Try it »
'_' Hline Try it »

content.text: Format Strings fmt
You can also use the shortcut string notation parameter to specify the marker.
content.html: You can also use the shortcut string notation parameter to specify the marker.

content.text: This parameter is also called fmt , and is written with this syntax:
content.html: This parameter is also called fmt, and is written with this syntax:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

ypoints = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])

plt.plot(ypoints, 'o:r')
plt.show()

content.code:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

ypoints = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])

plt.plot(ypoints, 'o:r')
plt.show()

syntax_highlighting.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

ypoints = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])

plt.plot(ypoints, 'o:r')
plt.show()

content.code_html:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

ypoints = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])

plt.plot(ypoints, 'o:r')
plt.show()

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

ypoints = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])

plt.plot(ypoints, 'o:r')
plt.show()

content.text: The marker value can be anything from the Marker Reference above.
content.html: The marker value can be anything from the Marker Reference above.

content.text: The line value can be one of the following:
content.html: The line value can be one of the following:

content.text: Line Reference

content.code_html:
Line Syntax Description
'-' Solid line Try it »
':' Dotted line Try it »
'--' Dashed line Try it »
'-.' Dashed/dotted line Try it »

content.text: Note: If you leave out the line value in the fmt parameter, no line will be plotted.
content.html: Note: If you leave out the line value in the fmt parameter, no line will be plotted.

content.text: The short color value can be one of the following:
content.html: The short color value can be one of the following:

content.text: Color Reference

content.code_html:
Color Syntax Description
'r' Red Try it »
'g' Green Try it »
'b' Blue Try it »
'c' Cyan Try it »
'm' Magenta Try it »
'y' Yellow Try it »
'k' Black Try it »
'w' White Try it »

content.text: Marker Size
You can use the keyword argument markersize or the shorter version, ms to set the size of the markers:
content.html: You can use the keyword argument markersize or the shorter version, ms to set the size of the markers:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

ypoints = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])

plt.plot(ypoints, marker = 'o', ms = 20)
plt.show()

content.code:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

ypoints = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])

plt.plot(ypoints, marker = 'o', ms = 20)
plt.show()

syntax_highlighting.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

ypoints = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])

plt.plot(ypoints, marker = 'o', ms = 20)
plt.show()

content.code_html:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

ypoints = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])

plt.plot(ypoints, marker = 'o', ms = 20)
plt.show()

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

ypoints = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])

plt.plot(ypoints, marker = 'o', ms = 20)
plt.show()

content.text: Marker Color
You can use the keyword argument markeredgecolor or the shorter mec to set the color of the edge of the markers:
content.html: You can use the keyword argument markeredgecolor or the shorter mec to set the color of the edge of the markers:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

ypoints = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])

plt.plot(ypoints, marker = 'o', ms = 20, mec = 'r')
plt.show()

content.code:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

ypoints = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])

plt.plot(ypoints, marker = 'o', ms = 20, mec = 'r')
plt.show()

syntax_highlighting.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

ypoints = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])

plt.plot(ypoints, marker = 'o', ms = 20, mec = 'r')
plt.show()

content.code_html:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

ypoints = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])

plt.plot(ypoints, marker = 'o', ms = 20, mec = 'r')
plt.show()

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

ypoints = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])

plt.plot(ypoints, marker = 'o', ms = 20, mec = 'r')
plt.show()

content.text: You can use the keyword argument markerfacecolor or the shorter mfc to set the color inside the edge of the markers:
content.html: You can use the keyword argument markerfacecolor or the shorter mfc to set the color inside the edge of the markers:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

ypoints = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])

plt.plot(ypoints, marker = 'o', ms = 20, mfc = 'r')
plt.show()

content.code:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

ypoints = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])

plt.plot(ypoints, marker = 'o', ms = 20, mfc = 'r')
plt.show()

content.text: Use both the mec and mfc arguments to color the entire marker:
content.html: Use both the mec and mfc arguments to color the entire marker:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

ypoints = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])

plt.plot(ypoints, marker = 'o', ms = 20, mec = 'r', mfc = 'r')
plt.show()

content.code:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

ypoints = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])

plt.plot(ypoints, marker = 'o', ms = 20, mec = 'r', mfc = 'r')
plt.show()

syntax_highlighting.text:

import numpy as np

ypoints = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])

plt.plot(ypoints, marker = 'o', ms = 20, mec = 'r', mfc = 'r')

import numpy as np

ypoints = np.array([3, 8, 1, 10])

plt.plot(ypoints, marker = 'o', ms = 20, mec = 'r', mfc = 'r')

content.text: You can also use Hexadecimal color values :

content.code_html:
...
plt.plot(ypoints, marker = 'o', ms = 20, mec = '#4CAF50', mfc = '#4CAF50')
...

content.text: Or any of the 140 supported color names .
content.html: Or any of the 140 supported color names.

content.code_html:
...
plt.plot(ypoints, marker = 'o', ms = 20, mec = 'hotpink', mfc = 'hotpink')
...
